msIdentifier.repository: Perne Library: on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library

foliation.p: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf.

signatures.p: Quire letters written in pencil in the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires.

note.p: A cropped word beginning 'Parche[...]' added in the 15th century to endleaf ii recto.
A 17th-century table of contents in the lower margin of f. 1r both parts of the manuscript: Lilium medicine / Gualterus de dosibus / Gerardus Cremonensis de modo medendi.

additions.note: f. 117r: The motto Viribus et ingenio' added by a (?) 15th-century hand

f. 117v: Verses, with the rubric: 'Condiciones boni medicine secundum Arnaldum de Villa noua'; beginning: 'Studens ingenio circumspectus medicando'; ending: 'Modestus sit benivolus summe hec operando'; and the final rubric: 'Isti uersus compos[u]it a magistri [sic] thoma Sutton' Added in the 15th century; Thomson (2016) suggests that 'Magister Thomas Sutton' was the namesake who became MA by 1464, MD from an unknown date, canon of Norton, Durham, from 1464 until his death in 1500.

binding.p: Earlier binding, presumably medieval, described in 1899 by M.R. James as 'pink skin over boards, two clasps gone: chain-mark at bottom of front cover'. Sewn on four bands, raised on the rounded spine. Remains of the stained skin may still be seen on the edges of the lifted pastedowns (f. i recto and f. 119v). The projecting, square-edged wooden boards have been reused in the present binding (see below).
Repaired by J.P. Gray, probably during the first half of the 20th century. Brown half leather binding with grey paper sides over wooden boards.

provenance.p: Owned by Thomas Deynman (fl. 1473, d. 1501), Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. 1473, d. 1501 , Bachelor of Medicine from an unidentified contintental university, physician to Henry VII and Lady Margaret Beaufort, fellow of Peterhouse from 21 April 1473, and Master from 19 November 1500 until his death in early 1501: his ownership inscriptions on f. ii verso: Constat Thome Deynman medico; followed by a price paid for the manuscript: Prec xvi s.; an ownership inscription on f. 108v: Liber thome deynman medici; and another one on f. 116v: Constat thome deynman.

history.acquisition: Probably bequeathed to Peterhouse by Thomas Deynman (fl. 1473, d. 1501), Bachelor of Medicine and Master of Peterhouse Deynman, Thomas, fl. 1473, d. 1501 . The manuscript is perhaps one of the twenty of his 'better books' that one of the fellows was allowed to select. It was certainly at Peterhouse by 1589 since it is recorded as no. 37 in the shelf-list (now Peterhouse MS 400) of the Peterhouse library's contents compiled c. 1589-1592 and entitled 'Nomina librorum qui erant in Bibliotheca Collegii ante Doctorem Perne mortuum' (The names of the books that were in the library of the college before the death of Doctor Perne). Perne died in 1592. The book was recorded again, several years later, in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600), as no. 213. Peterhouse's ownership stamp on ff. 1r, 66r, and 116v.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, A descriptive catalogue of the manuscripts in the library of Peterhouse (1899)>; and R.M. Thomson, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Medieval Manuscripts in the Library of Peterhouse, Cambridge (2016), by kind permission of the author. Readers of this record are encouraged to consult Thomson's Catalogue for further information about this manuscript.

availability.p: The manuscripts of Peterhouse are stored on long-term deposit at Cambridge University Library. Readers wishing to consult a Peterhouse manuscript in-person will need to visit the University Library. Entry to read in Cambridge University Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msItem.title: Lilium medicinae
msItem.author: Bernard de Gordon
msItem.rubric: 1r Incipit lilium medicine Magistri B. de Gor.
msItem.incipit: 1r Inter[o]gatus a quodam Socrates quomodo possit optime dicere
msItem.explicit: 105v Intelligendum est hic quod nos ordinauimus per Dei gratiam iiii. opuscula diu est propter isud opus et si adderentur hic esset opus perfecit magisterii scilicet libellus de regimine acutorum morborum et libellus de crisi et de diebus creticis et libellus qui intitulatur tabula ingeniorum et sine ista factum est nihil et libellus de graduacione.
msItem.finalRubric: 105v Expletus est liber benedictus Deus in secula. Bene possum igitur dicere hoc opus exegi quod nec Iouis ira nec ignes nec ferrum nec edax abolere uetustas. Fuit scriptus liber iste anno incarnacionis Domini M CCC IIII die sancte agathe uirginis. Dextera scriptoris benedicta sit omnibus horis.
msItem.note: Containing many marginal annotations with recipes in various Italian hands.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Added by two or more 14th-century hands.

msItem.title: De dosibus medicinarum
msItem.author: Walter Agilon
msItem.rubric: 106r Incipit liber de dosi secundum Galterum magistrum
msItem.incipit: 106r Medicinarum quedam sunt simplices et quedam composite
msItem.explicit: 108v et hec de dosi medicinarum dicta sufficiant
msItem.finalRubric: 108v Explicit liber de dosi medicinarum secundum Galterum. Deo gracias.

signatures.p: Letters combined with Roman numerals or horizontal lines.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in brown ink in the lower right-hand corner of the last versos of the quires.

supportDesc.condition: There is a large cut in the middle of f. 116.

layout.seg: Ruled in crayon, frame and line ruling. Double columns. 52-53 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: ff. 1r-108v have been written by a single scribe in in Gothica Rotunda.

decoNote.p: Three- to seven-line puzzle initials in blue and red with penwork decoration inside the letter and pen-flourishing in both colours (ff. 1r [x2], 22r, 40r, 52v, 65v, 82v, 94v.
Two-line initials in blue or red with pen-work decoration in the opposite colour.
Rubrics have either been written in red ink or written in brown ink and struck through with a red horizontal line.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.

msItem.title: Summo de modo medendi
msItem.author: Gerard of Montpellier [Cremona]
msItem.rubric: 109r Incipit summa magistri Geraldi Cremonensis de modo medendi et ordine quo corpus sit purgandum
msItem.incipit: 109r [C]um omnis sciencia ex suo fine et utilitate sua

supportDesc.condition: The leaves of this part are very cockled.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Double columns. 64-66 lines to the page written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe in a Gothic Rotunda script.

decoDesc.p: This part of the manuscript does not contains any significant form of decoration.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer, Cambridge University Library
